pages.text: $(#8B4513)$(l)【Blazing Bitter Aroma】$()$(br2)“In the sun-scorched valleys, a rich and slightly bitter fragrance lingers in the air.”$(br2)Wild coffee grows abundantly in tropical highlands, its lush green foliage bearing fruits that start off green and ripen into a deep red. Once harvested, the beans are roasted over fire, releasing an intoxicating aroma. Explorers often rely on its invigorating essence to stay alert on long and arduous journeys.

Commonly found in hot and humid valleys, thriving under high temperatures and ample sunlight. Its flowers are pure white and delicate, with a very short blooming period. The berries are packed with rich compounds that only reveal their true bitterness after roasting.

Excerpt from *Traveler’s Notes*$(br)“The first time I inhaled that sharp yet rich aroma, it felt as though I had stepped into a forge shaped by sunlight itself. The bitterness scorched my tongue, yet an unseen force pulled me forward, guiding me across the endless wilderness.”

Roasted coffee beans are ground and brewed into a deep, midnight-colored liquid, its aroma as sharp as fire licking at the soul. Upon drinking, one's spirit is ignited, as if embracing the warmth of the sun itself.$(br2)$(#8B4513)But be wary—though the bitter aroma is uplifting, lingering too long in its grasp may leave one sleepless beneath the night sky…$()
